narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: the mathematics and physical principles underlying mechanics, from basic kinematics to oscillations to relativity
I learned what the syllabus says on it.
Classical Mechanics
I learned more about classical physical systems and how to mathematically represent them.

I gained a more refined understanding of mechanics as understood through classical physics. I also learned about topics unfamiliar to me such as coupled oscillations and dynamic systems. Overall, this course taught me a mathematical formalism I can use in future work in mechanics.
A basic understanding of different applications of Newtonian mechanics, and a surface-level coverage of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of mechanics.
Basic skills on Lagrangian mechanics, inertia tensors, and coupled oscillators.

This course generally covers very similar material to PHYS 180 or 200, but at a higher level and introducing new elements. For example, when we covered rotational dynamics, the idea of the moment of inertia tensor was introduced, as opposed to just the single moment of inertia we learned in introductory physics. Possibly the most important topic was that of the Hamiltonian and Lagrangian methods for approaching problems, which allowed us to approach more complex systems than those studied in earlier courses.
Lagrangian/Hamiltonian mechanics.

Pretty much what you'd expectit's the unit on mechanics (and relativity, apparently) from your intro physics course stretched out into a semester long force balancing equations of motion deriving extravaganza.
BASIC level of intermediate classical mechanics
Review of HS classical mechanics, Lagrangians, Hamiltonians (a bit), Coupled Oscillators, Special Relativity,
Classical mechanics, including the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulation, rotational dynamics and special relativity
Mainly the techniques found in Thornton and Marion.
This course was a recap of Classical Mechanics. Having taken 260, it didn't really add much new information, apart from the methods of Lagrange and Hamilton, which only took a week or two to cover.
Introduction to mechanics following the Thornton + Marion textbook closely.
Basic knowledge of Lagrangians and Hamiltonians.

Knowledge of various topics in mechanics, including Euler Lagrange equation and calculus of variations, non inertial reference frames, gravity, dynamics of a system of particles, rigid bodies, coupled oscillations, and special relativity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Baker was the strength of the class. He was kind, approachable, and funny, and he made the class much less stressful. The workload was reasonable and never overwhelming
While the concepts are generally very interesting and important, they sometimes lacked motivation and it seemed like we were just doing random math without any real background.
There is a big emphasis on hw and qualitative understanding over exams and quantitative (mathy) stuff, which i find to be great. I think most would agree.
Strengths: Better than 401 by a long shot

I like that many different topics are covered in depth, and think the exposure to more advanced mathematics in a physics context is very good for prospective majors. However, I think problem sets could be a bit more challenging and lectures could focus more on conceptualization rather than going over every step of mathematical results.

The strength of this course is that it delves deeply into the mathematics behind topics covered in an introductory mechanics class, allowing students to solve a broader range of problems, many more complex than one might have seen before. It also explores topics that may have been covered only briefly in an introductory course, such as coupled oscillations and special relativity. Assigning textbook readings might improve this course, as the material really does come straight from the textbook (and Classical Dynamics is a fantastic book that students in the class should not only be encouraged, but required to read).

Strengths: Prof Baker provided clear lecture notes (that students often referred to instead going to lecture itself); the exams were ridiculously-easy, comprised of 'conceptual', multiple-choice-questions that tested a basic understanding of the definitions and equations described in class, without evaluating a student's problem solving ability whatsoever. Weaknesses: the lectures were almost always unnecessarily confusing, as derivations and problems were often botched on the blackboard. Barring Prof Baker's entertaining anecdotes from his professional life, there was little academic motivation to go to lecture. Furthermore, this course should not be listed as a substitute for, and not a succession to the intro course PHYS 260. I learnt far more physics in PHYS 260, to the point that barring the cursory introduction to Lagrangians and Hamiltonians, the syllabus for PHYS 410 was essentially a subset of what we learnt in PHYS 260.

The strength was the low workload and general low stakes of the class. A weakness was the lectures themselves. Another not so big weakness was that the tests were oftentimes confusing. 

I wish the course would go directly into the new topics instead of covering the exact same topics as in the intro courses. I felt very bored.

I think the course is a good course, but there were some problems with the professor that made it very difficult for the course to be enjoyable. I think more focus should have been spent on Hamiltonian and Lagrangian methods. Also, I felt that the exams and psets were unreasonable at times. Overall, I felt like I would have enjoyed the class if it were not for the fact that I did not understand the material well enough to find it interesting.
I wish there was more time spent really digging into lagrangian, and especially hamiltonian, mechanics.

It felt at times like lecture notes were a more confusing version of the textbook, and lectures themselves were a more confusing version of the lecture notes. That's not to say lecture was uselessif you came in with specific questions, Prof Baker was quite accommodating, and that did serve to clarify issues that we were fuzzy on going into the lecture. Sometimes these would turn into full on tangent mini-lessons, though, which were fine until they started running up against the course deadlines. Baker was good about handling that, though, and there wasn't any sort of nightmare scenario where we were expected to know material we didn't have time to cover in class. I think one of the greatest improvements the course could see is just in terms of logistical smoothnessit sometimes took a while to get responses to emails, the syllabus and lecture notes often needed amending, and things of that nature. I don't want to make it sound like these were deal breakersthey aren'tbut all things being equal it'd be nice to have our schedule laid out form the start. One big upside is Baker's philosophy on exams; essentially, psets are for proving you can do long, arduous math, and exams are for demonstrating conceptual mastery. You won't lose a bunch of points on a super important test because you made arithmetic errors or forgot one relatively obscure equation, which I found to be just a better way of doing things.
There isn't a strength tbh, the material is quite standard. Weakness: we try to cover too many different areas/chapters.

Prof. Baker is a massive strength of this class. He is incredibly kind, approachable, and cares a lot about his students. However, that being said, this course was a little too easy to be an upper-division physics course. In an effort to emulate graduate entrance exams, Prof. Baker made exams in this class entirely MC. While this was nice at the moment, a certain level of rigor was lost by not having to study for these exams. We also did not cover some core classical mechanic subjects (Noether's theorem) and spent too much time on introductory level material (we spent a full class drawing force diagrams).
Prof Baker has very detailed notes and follows the textbook in content, so it is easy to keep up with the class contents
Hopefully your instructor covers additional and/or engaging topics. Classical mechanics can be rather dry if it does not have a good problem-solving feel to it.

Strengths: Very easy course and professor Baker is very nice and caring.
Weaknesses: I don't feel like I learned lots of new material, and to be honest the lectures were not great.

Strengths: content. 
Weaknesses: comically easy exams, Professor Baker's teaching style.

Problem sets are good, but could be more difficult. Lecture was good until Prof Baker started reading from slides and notes, then it was less good. Exams are different but not as difficult as they could be if they were problem based rather than comprehension based.

The lectures were full of math mistakes that made it difficult to follow. We eventually covered a chapter a week, so the more interesting parts of the chapters were skipped. Likewise, the problem set problems were not difficult or interesting at all, and didn't showcase what could be done with the new techniques we learned. 
Midterm and Final were MC tests (a lot of which had 2 - 3 choices) that tested reading skills more than anything else. Their difficulty was comparable to intro high school physics exams. 
Hard to say I learned much from the class.

Strengths: It is a pretty easy course. Exams were multiple choice and easy, problem sets usually didn't take long. Professor Baker is kind and understanding about potential issues.

Weaknesses: I didn't learn a lot in this course, mostly because I didn't have to learn a lot to score well. Lectures were often dominated by doing examples that didn't really teach the material, and some of that time was lost with Prof. Baker getting lost in his notes. I also think that the emphasis should be on the entirely new material (Lagrangian and Hamiltonian) because it is important in future courses, but we only spent a week or two on that.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, take any class with Professor Baker.
Yes, Baker is legit a homie. My man is a vibe, my man is a real one, my man is the GOAT!
Sure.
I would recommend looking into the other classical mechanics class taught by the DUS of the physics major. This class seemed to go both in more depth and cover more than this one.

If you intend to major in physics, I would encourage you to take this course. The problem sets are where the real work of the course comes in; the midterm and final are more conceptual and less challenging. Overall, however, the workload of this course is relatively light, but the material is very engaging.
This is currently a required course for the intensive Physics major - only take it if you have to.
Yes, if they can skip 260 by taking this course they should.

I would not recommend this course, at least with the professor we had. It was very difficult to go to lecture, because it felt like I would have learned just as much from reading the textbook for the same amount of time. I do not feel like I have a very thorough understanding of most anything we learned.
Yes, it's definitely one of the easiest classes I've taken at Yale, but it remained pretty interesting (and it's required for the intensive major).

I'd recommend it, because if you're here, you're a physics major (or a math major trying to get a BS, in which case this is definitely the one for you). The exams were all multiple choice conceptual questions, which meant that they were really more focused on testing whether you were paying attention in class than whether or not you can complete some Sisyphean mechanics problem. The psets weren't the worst, the material is somewhat interesting, and you should be able to get through just fine.

For math majors looking for advanced natural science credits, yes. It's kinda easy.
For others, no.

Yes and No. If you want an easy science credit and you have a strong mathematical background, this class is an absolute gut. However, if you want a rigorous and well-developed understanding of classical mechanics you are better served by taking the graduate version of this class.
The problem sets can get quite mathematically involved at times, but otherwise it is a great first step towards the advanced physics elective classes.
Yes. If they learn well from reading the textbook they could get a lot out of it. I found the lectures useful as a supplement to the book, but not always on their own.
Yes, so long as the professor is not Baker.

I recommend this course to physics majors and math students looking for an easy science course. The class is engaging but exams are very light, so a student looking for a more rigorous treatment is the material might look to other mechanics classes.
No, but it's required for the intensive physics major. This class is however easier than its lower level counterpart (401). Lectures are full of mistakes and the pset problems are not interesting.

I wouldn't necessarily recommend this course if you are trying to learn classical mechanics. From what I have heard, PHYS 401 teaches the same (or similar) material but it is taught well. With that being said, PHYS 410 is easy and it is a requirement for the intensive major, so if you are looking for an easy course, take this.
